context: Both models define the chromatographic retention factor (k) as the key parameter determining the breakthrough volume since, for a limited range of flow-rates and a specified sampling system, changes in hold-up volume and plate number provide only a marginal change in breakthrough volume, provided that N and V M are not very small. Then, the distribution coefficient K can be seen as an indirect measure of the retention factor. In this work, both parameters (breakthrough volume and distribution coefficient), as well as others relevant in chromatographic theory such as the height equivalent to a theoretical plate (H) and the asymmetry factor (F a) are monitored to check the feasibility of two relatively new SPE polymeric resins, Bond Elut ENV (styrene-divinylbenzene) and LiChrolut EN (ethylvinylbenzene-divinylbenzene) in gas sampling followed by thermal desorption. The behavior of these new generation resins is compared to the most widespread sorbent, Tenax TA, in trapping-desorbing some volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as 1-octene, ethylbenzene, (o-, m-, p-)xylenes, styrene and 1,4-dichlorobenzene. Materials The chemical standards used and their corresponding CAS numbers were the following: 1-octene (98%, 111-66-0); and ethylbenzene (99.5%, 100-42-5) were purchased from Aldrich (Madrid, Spain). Styrene (99%, 100-42-5), o-xylene (99%, 95-47-6), m-xylene (99%, 108-38-3, 1.2mgkg−1), p-xylene (99%, 106-42-3) and dichlorobenzene (99%, 106-46-7) were supplied by Fluka-Riedel de Häen (Madrid, Spain). Each chemical was diluted up to 1% using ethyl ether (GC quality) as solvent.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,4-dichlorobenzene is evaluated as one of the volatile organic compounds (VOCs) trapped and desorbed using Tenax TA, a widely used sorbent in gas sampling. The study compares the performance of Tenax TA with newer polymeric resins in terms of their ability to capture and release various VOCs, including 1,4-dichlorobenzene. This indicates a direct functional relationship where Tenax serves as a medium for analyzing the behavior of 1,4-dichlorobenzene in chromatographic processes.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 4 reflects a significant connection between 1,4-dichlorobenzene and Tenax, as the context discusses their interaction in the specific application of gas sampling and thermal desorption, supported by comparative analysis.
